Comment: This is one of the most famous games in chess, justly known as the "Evergreen" game.
The most aggressive square for the LSB. Controls d5, and bites down on the weak f7 pawn.
The most aggressive square for the LSB. Controls d5, and bites down on the weak f7 pawn.
The most aggressive square for the LSB. Controls d5, and bites down on the weak f7 pawn.
The most aggressive square for the LSB. Controls d5, and bites down on the weak f7 pawn.
In turn biting down on the weak f2 square.
Evans gambit, a sharp try for control of the center and attacks on f7.
And black accepts, the best move here.
This is the point of the Evans gambit.
Retreating the DSB while keeping the pressure on c3. Matter of fact, this is the only black move that prevents white from getting a keepable pawn center with d4.
Anderssen plays 6 d4 anyway. Notice that the c3 pawn is pinned.
Black takes while keeping c3 pinned.
The natural move, removing the pin on c3, which enables white a pawn center if given the opportunity, while activating the rook to slide over to the critical e file.

!? Opts to keep the d file closed and slow down white's development, since he is betting white will take. Black effectively prevented the strong pawn center, but lost lots of time, and now the attack will begin. Better was 7 ... dxc3.

Attacking the weak pawn. Usually the fast attacks in the opening when black is slow castling come on f7. Notice white does not defend the hanging d pawn...white will have plenty of chances to take this pawn later. It cannot be defended easily by black.
Defends f7 while double-attacking c3.
Black cannot take this; 9 ... Qxe5 10 Re1! Or 9 ... Nxe5 10 Re1 and now the knight is pinned.
Retreating while still defending f7.

White now grabs the critical e file. Although the e file is not yet open, white puts tremendous pressure on the center. For example, black cannot play 10 ... d6 11 exd6+, and white is poised to play the battering ram pawn push e6. The e5 pawn is a thorn in black's side.
Extremely powerful position for white's DSB as it puts incredible pressure on the centralized black king.
Extremely powerful position for white's DSB as it puts incredible pressure on the centralized black king.
? A foolish try since black is not castled. Better is 11 ... 0-0.
Taking the free offering.
Grabbing the b file and attacking white's queen.
